94def _deprecate_argsort_axis(arr): 

95 """ 

96 Adjust the axis passed to argsort, warning if necessary 

97 

98 Parameters 

99 ---------- 

100 arr 

101 The array which argsort was called on 

102 

103 np.ma.argsort has a long-term bug where the default of the axis argument 

104 is wrong (gh-8701), which now must be kept for backwards compatibiity. 

105 Thankfully, this only makes a difference when arrays are 2- or more- 

106 dimensional, so we only need a warning then. 

107 """ 

108 if arr.ndim <= 1: 

109 # no warning needed - but switch to -1 anyway, to avoid surprising 

110 # subclasses, which are more likely to implement scalar axes. 

111 return -1 

112 else: 

113 # 2017-04-11, Numpy 1.13.0, gh-8701: warn on axis default 

114 warnings.warn( 

115 "In the future the default for argsort will be axis=-1, not the " 

116 "current None, to match its documentation and np.argsort. " 

117 "Explicitly pass -1 or None to silence this warning.", 

118 MaskedArrayFutureWarning, stacklevel=3) 

119 return None

122def doc_note(initialdoc, note): 

123 """ 

124 Adds a Notes section to an existing docstring. 

125 

126 """ 

127 if initialdoc is None: 

128 return 

129 if note is None: 

130 return initialdoc 

131 

132 notesplit = re.split(r'\n\s*?Notes\n\s*?-----', initialdoc) 

133 

134 notedoc = """\ 

135Notes 

136 ----- 

137 %s""" % note 

138 

139 if len(notesplit) > 1: 

140 notedoc = '\n\n ' + notedoc + '\n' 

141 

142 return ''.join(notesplit[:1] + [notedoc] + notesplit[1:])

145def get_object_signature(obj): 

146 """ 

147 Get the signature from obj 

148 

149 """ 

150 try: 

151 sig = formatargspec(*getargspec(obj)) 

152 except TypeError: 

153 sig = '' 

154 return sig

178############################################################################### 

179# Filling options # 

180############################################################################### 

181 

182 

183# b: boolean - c: complex - f: floats - i: integer - O: object - S: string 

184default_filler = {'b': True, 

185 'c': 1.e20 + 0.0j, 

186 'f': 1.e20, 

187 'i': 999999, 

188 'O': '?', 

189 'S': b'N/A', 

190 'u': 999999, 

191 'V': b'???', 

192 'U': u'N/A' 

193 } 

194 

195# Add datetime64 and timedelta64 types 

196for v in ["Y", "M", "W", "D", "h", "m", "s", "ms", "us", "ns", "ps", 

197 "fs", "as"]: 

198 default_filler["M8[" + v + "]"] = np.datetime64("NaT", v) 

199 default_filler["m8[" + v + "]"] = np.timedelta64("NaT", v) 

200 

201max_filler = ntypes._minvals 

202max_filler.update([(k, -np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]]) 

203min_filler = ntypes._maxvals 

204min_filler.update([(k, +np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]]) 

205if 'float128' in ntypes.typeDict: 

206 max_filler.update([(np.float128, -np.inf)]) 

207 min_filler.update([(np.float128, +np.inf)]) 

208 

209 

210def _recursive_fill_value(dtype, f): 

211 """ 

212 Recursively produce a fill value for `dtype`, calling f on scalar dtypes 

213 """ 

214 if dtype.names is not None: 

215 vals = tuple(_recursive_fill_value(dtype[name], f) for name in dtype.names) 

216 return np.array(vals, dtype=dtype)[()] # decay to void scalar from 0d 

217 elif dtype.subdtype: 

218 subtype, shape = dtype.subdtype 

219 subval = _recursive_fill_value(subtype, f) 

220 return np.full(shape, subval) 

221 else: 

222 return f(dtype) 

223 

224 

225def _get_dtype_of(obj): 

226 """ Convert the argument for *_fill_value into a dtype """ 

227 if isinstance(obj, np.dtype): 

228 return obj 

229 elif hasattr(obj, 'dtype'): 

230 return obj.dtype 

231 else: 

232 return np.asanyarray(obj).dtype

234 

235def default_fill_value(obj): 

236 """ 

237 Return the default fill value for the argument object. 

238 

239 The default filling value depends on the datatype of the input 

240 array or the type of the input scalar: 

241 

242 ======== ======== 

243 datatype default 

244 ======== ======== 

245 bool True 

246 int 999999 

247 float 1.e20 

248 complex 1.e20+0j 

249 object '?' 

250 string 'N/A' 

251 ======== ======== 

252 

253 For structured types, a structured scalar is returned, with each field the 

254 default fill value for its type. 

255 

256 For subarray types, the fill value is an array of the same size containing 

257 the default scalar fill value. 

258 

259 Parameters 

260 ---------- 

261 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

262 The array data-type or scalar for which the default fill value 

263 is returned. 

264 

265 Returns 

266 ------- 

267 fill_value : scalar 

268 The default fill value. 

269 

270 Examples 

271 -------- 

272 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(1) 

273 999999 

274 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.array([1.1, 2., np.pi])) 

275 1e+20 

276 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.dtype(complex)) 

277 (1e+20+0j) 

278 

279 """ 

280 def _scalar_fill_value(dtype): 

281 if dtype.kind in 'Mm': 

282 return default_filler.get(dtype.str[1:], '?') 

283 else: 

284 return default_filler.get(dtype.kind, '?') 

285 

286 dtype = _get_dtype_of(obj) 

287 return _recursive_fill_value(dtype, _scalar_fill_value) 

288 

289 

290def _extremum_fill_value(obj, extremum, extremum_name): 

291 

292 def _scalar_fill_value(dtype): 

293 try: 

294 return extremum[dtype] 

295 except KeyError: 

296 raise TypeError( 

297 "Unsuitable type {} for calculating {}." 

298 .format(dtype, extremum_name) 

299 ) 

300 

301 dtype = _get_dtype_of(obj) 

302 return _recursive_fill_value(dtype, _scalar_fill_value) 

303 

304 

305def minimum_fill_value(obj): 

306 """ 

307 Return the maximum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object. 

308 

309 This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for 

310 taking the minimum of an array with a given dtype. 

311 

312 Parameters 

313 ---------- 

314 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

315 An object that can be queried for it's numeric type. 

316 

317 Returns 

318 ------- 

319 val : scalar 

320 The maximum representable value. 

321 

322 Raises 

323 ------ 

324 TypeError 

325 If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type. 

326 

327 See Also 

328 -------- 

329 maximum_fill_value : The inverse function. 

330 set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array. 

331 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

332 

333 Examples 

334 -------- 

335 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

336 >>> a = np.int8() 

337 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

338 127 

339 >>> a = np.int32() 

340 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

341 2147483647 

342 

343 An array of numeric data can also be passed. 

344 

345 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.int8) 

346 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

347 127 

348 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32) 

349 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

350 inf 

351 

352 """ 

353 return _extremum_fill_value(obj, min_filler, "minimum") 

354

357 """ 

358 Return the minimum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object. 

359 

360 This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for 

361 taking the maximum of an array with a given dtype. 

362 

363 Parameters 

364 ---------- 

365 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

366 An object that can be queried for it's numeric type. 

367 

368 Returns 

369 ------- 

370 val : scalar 

371 The minimum representable value. 

372 

373 Raises 

374 ------ 

375 TypeError 

376 If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type. 

377 

378 See Also 

379 -------- 

380 minimum_fill_value : The inverse function. 

381 set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array. 

382 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

383 

384 Examples 

385 -------- 

386 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

387 >>> a = np.int8() 

388 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a)

395

397 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a) 

398 -128 

399 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32)

407def _recursive_set_fill_value(fillvalue, dt): 

408 """ 

409 Create a fill value for a structured dtype. 

410 

411 Parameters 

412 ---------- 

413 fillvalue: scalar or array_like 

414 Scalar or array representing the fill value. If it is of shorter 

415 length than the number of fields in dt, it will be resized. 

416 dt: dtype 

417 The structured dtype for which to create the fill value. 

418 

419 Returns 

420 ------- 

421 val: tuple 

422 A tuple of values corresponding to the structured fill value. 

423 

424 """ 

425 fillvalue = np.resize(fillvalue, len(dt.names)) 

426 output_value = [] 

427 for (fval, name) in zip(fillvalue, dt.names): 

428 cdtype = dt[name] 

429 if cdtype.subdtype: 

430 cdtype = cdtype.subdtype[0] 

431 

432 if cdtype.names is not None: 

433 output_value.append(tuple(_recursive_set_fill_value(fval, cdtype))) 

434 else: 

435 output_value.append(np.array(fval, dtype=cdtype).item()) 

436 return tuple(output_value) 

437 

438 

439def _check_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype): 

440 """ 

441 Private function validating the given `fill_value` for the given dtype. 

442 

443 If fill_value is None, it is set to the default corresponding to the dtype. 

444 

445 If fill_value is not None, its value is forced to the given dtype. 

446 

447 The result is always a 0d array. 

448 

449 """ 

450 ndtype = np.dtype(ndtype) 

451 if fill_value is None: 

452 fill_value = default_fill_value(ndtype) 

453 elif ndtype.names is not None: 

454 if isinstance(fill_value, (ndarray, np.void)): 

455 try: 

456 fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=ndtype) 

457 except ValueError: 

458 err_msg = "Unable to transform %s to dtype %s" 

459 raise ValueError(err_msg % (fill_value, ndtype)) 

460 else: 

461 fill_value = np.asarray(fill_value, dtype=object) 

462 fill_value = np.array(_recursive_set_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype), 

463 dtype=ndtype) 

464 else: 

465 if isinstance(fill_value, basestring) and (ndtype.char not in 'OSVU'): 

466 # Note this check doesn't work if fill_value is not a scalar 

467 err_msg = "Cannot set fill value of string with array of dtype %s" 

468 raise TypeError(err_msg % ndtype) 

469 else: 

470 # In case we want to convert 1e20 to int. 

471 # Also in case of converting string arrays. 

472 try: 

473 fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=ndtype) 

474 except (OverflowError, ValueError): 

475 # Raise TypeError instead of OverflowError or ValueError. 

476 # OverflowError is seldom used, and the real problem here is 

477 # that the passed fill_value is not compatible with the ndtype. 

478 err_msg = "Cannot convert fill_value %s to dtype %s" 

479 raise TypeError(err_msg % (fill_value, ndtype)) 

480 return np.array(fill_value)

483def set_fill_value(a, fill_value): 

484 """ 

485 Set the filling value of a, if a is a masked array. 

486 

487 This function changes the fill value of the masked array `a` in place. 

488 If `a` is not a masked array, the function returns silently, without 

489 doing anything. 

490 

491 Parameters 

492 ---------- 

493 a : array_like 

494 Input array. 

495 fill_value : dtype 

496 Filling value. A consistency test is performed to make sure 

497 the value is compatible with the dtype of `a`. 

498 

499 Returns 

500 ------- 

501 None 

502 Nothing returned by this function. 

503 

504 See Also 

505 -------- 

506 maximum_fill_value : Return the default fill value for a dtype. 

507 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

508 MaskedArray.set_fill_value : Equivalent method. 

509 

510 Examples 

511 -------- 

512 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

513 >>> a = np.arange(5) 

514 >>> a 

515 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

516 >>> a = ma.masked_where(a < 3, a) 

517 >>> a 

518 masked_array(data=[--, --, --, 3, 4], 

519 mask=[ True, True, True, False, False], 

520 fill_value=999999) 

521 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, -999) 

522 >>> a 

523 masked_array(data=[--, --, --, 3, 4], 

524 mask=[ True, True, True, False, False], 

525 fill_value=-999) 

526 

527 Nothing happens if `a` is not a masked array. 

528 

529 >>> a = list(range(5)) 

530 >>> a 

531 [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] 

532 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100) 

533 >>> a 

534 [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] 

535 >>> a = np.arange(5) 

536 >>> a 

537 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

538 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100) 

539 >>> a 

540 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

541 

542 """ 

543 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

544 a.set_fill_value(fill_value) 

545 return 

546 

547 

548def get_fill_value(a): 

549 """ 

550 Return the filling value of a, if any. Otherwise, returns the 

551 default filling value for that type. 

552 

553 """ 

554 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

555 result = a.fill_value 

556 else: 

557 result = default_fill_value(a) 

558 return result 

559 

560 

561def common_fill_value(a, b): 

562 """ 

563 Return the common filling value of two masked arrays, if any. 

564 

565 If ``a.fill_value == b.fill_value``, return the fill value, 

566 otherwise return None. 

567 

568 Parameters 

569 ---------- 

570 a, b : MaskedArray 

571 The masked arrays for which to compare fill values. 

572 

573 Returns 

574 ------- 

575 fill_value : scalar or None 

576 The common fill value, or None. 

577 

578 Examples 

579 -------- 

580 >>> x = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3) 

581 >>> y = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3) 

582 >>> np.ma.common_fill_value(x, y) 

583 3.0 

584 

585 """ 

586 t1 = get_fill_value(a) 

587 t2 = get_fill_value(b) 

588 if t1 == t2: 

589 return t1 

590 return None

593def filled(a, fill_value=None): 

594 """ 

595 Return input as an array with masked data replaced by a fill value. 

596 

597 If `a` is not a `MaskedArray`, `a` itself is returned. 

598 If `a` is a `MaskedArray` and `fill_value` is None, `fill_value` is set to 

599 ``a.fill_value``. 

600 

601 Parameters 

602 ---------- 

603 a : MaskedArray or array_like 

604 An input object. 

605 fill_value : array_like, optional. 

606 Can be scalar or non-scalar. If non-scalar, the 

607 resulting filled array should be broadcastable 

608 over input array. Default is None. 

609 

610 Returns 

611 ------- 

612 a : ndarray 

613 The filled array. 

614 

615 See Also 

616 -------- 

617 compressed 

618 

619 Examples 

620 -------- 

621 >>> x = np.ma.array(np.arange(9).reshape(3, 3), mask=[[1, 0, 0], 

622 ... [1, 0, 0], 

623 ... [0, 0, 0]]) 

624 >>> x.filled() 

625 array([[999999, 1, 2], 

626 [999999, 4, 5], 

627 [ 6, 7, 8]]) 

628 >>> x.filled(fill_value=333) 

629 array([[333, 1, 2], 

630 [333, 4, 5], 

631 [ 6, 7, 8]]) 

632 >>> x.filled(fill_value=np.arange(3)) 

633 array([[0, 1, 2], 

634 [0, 4, 5], 

635 [6, 7, 8]]) 

636 

637 """ 

638 if hasattr(a, 'filled'): 

639 return a.filled(fill_value) 

640 

641 elif isinstance(a, ndarray): 

642 # Should we check for contiguity ? and a.flags['CONTIGUOUS']: 

643 return a 

644 elif isinstance(a, dict): 

645 return np.array(a, 'O') 

646 else: 

647 return np.array(a) 

648 

649 

650def get_masked_subclass(*arrays): 

651 """ 

652 Return the youngest subclass of MaskedArray from a list of (masked) arrays. 

653 

654 In case of siblings, the first listed takes over. 

655 

656 """ 

657 if len(arrays) == 1: 

658 arr = arrays[0] 

659 if isinstance(arr, MaskedArray): 

660 rcls = type(arr) 

661 else: 

662 rcls = MaskedArray 

663 else: 

664 arrcls = [type(a) for a in arrays] 

665 rcls = arrcls[0] 

666 if not issubclass(rcls, MaskedArray): 

667 rcls = MaskedArray 

668 for cls in arrcls[1:]: 

669 if issubclass(cls, rcls): 

670 rcls = cls 

671 # Don't return MaskedConstant as result: revert to MaskedArray 

672 if rcls.__name__ == 'MaskedConstant': 

673 return MaskedArray 

674 return rcls

677def getdata(a, subok=True): 

678 """ 

679 Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

680 

681 Return the data of `a` (if any) as an ndarray if `a` is a ``MaskedArray``, 

682 else return `a` as a ndarray or subclass (depending on `subok`) if not. 

683 

684 Parameters 

685 ---------- 

686 a : array_like 

687 Input ``MaskedArray``, alternatively a ndarray or a subclass thereof. 

688 subok : bool 

689 Whether to force the output to be a `pure` ndarray (False) or to 

690 return a subclass of ndarray if appropriate (True, default). 

691 

692 See Also 

693 -------- 

694 getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

695 getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False. 

696 

697 Examples 

698 -------- 

699 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

700 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

701 >>> a 

702 masked_array( 

703 data=[[1, --], 

704 [3, 4]], 

705 mask=[[False, True], 

706 [False, False]], 

707 fill_value=2) 

708 >>> ma.getdata(a) 

709 array([[1, 2], 

710 [3, 4]]) 

711 

712 Equivalently use the ``MaskedArray`` `data` attribute. 

713 

714 >>> a.data 

715 array([[1, 2], 

716 [3, 4]]) 

717 

718 """ 

719 try: 

720 data = a._data 

721 except AttributeError: 

722 data = np.array(a, copy=False, subok=subok) 

723 if not subok: 

724 return data.view(ndarray) 

725 return data 

726 

727 

728get_data = getdata 

729 

730 

731def fix_invalid(a, mask=nomask, copy=True, fill_value=None): 

732 """ 

733 Return input with invalid data masked and replaced by a fill value. 

734 

735 Invalid data means values of `nan`, `inf`, etc. 

736 

737 Parameters 

738 ---------- 

739 a : array_like 

740 Input array, a (subclass of) ndarray. 

741 mask : sequence, optional 

742 Mask. Must be convertible to an array of booleans with the same 

743 shape as `data`. True indicates a masked (i.e. invalid) data. 

744 copy : bool, optional 

745 Whether to use a copy of `a` (True) or to fix `a` in place (False). 

746 Default is True. 

747 fill_value : scalar, optional 

748 Value used for fixing invalid data. Default is None, in which case 

749 the ``a.fill_value`` is used. 

750 

751 Returns 

752 ------- 

753 b : MaskedArray 

754 The input array with invalid entries fixed. 

755 

756 Notes 

757 ----- 

758 A copy is performed by default. 

759 

760 Examples 

761 -------- 

762 >>> x = np.ma.array([1., -1, np.nan, np.inf], mask=[1] + [0]*3) 

763 >>> x 

764 masked_array(data=[--, -1.0, nan, inf], 

765 mask=[ True, False, False, False], 

766 fill_value=1e+20) 

767 >>> np.ma.fix_invalid(x) 

768 masked_array(data=[--, -1.0, --, --], 

769 mask=[ True, False, True, True], 

770 fill_value=1e+20) 

771 

772 >>> fixed = np.ma.fix_invalid(x) 

773 >>> fixed.data 

774 array([ 1.e+00, -1.e+00, 1.e+20, 1.e+20]) 

775 >>> x.data 

776 array([ 1., -1., nan, inf]) 

777 

778 """ 

779 a = masked_array(a, copy=copy, mask=mask, subok=True) 

780 invalid = np.logical_not(np.isfinite(a._data)) 

781 if not invalid.any(): 

782 return a 

783 a._mask |= invalid 

784 if fill_value is None: 

785 fill_value = a.fill_value 

786 a._data[invalid] = fill_value 

787 return a 

788 

789def is_string_or_list_of_strings(val): 

790 return (isinstance(val, basestring) or 

791 (isinstance(val, list) and val and 

792 builtins.all(isinstance(s, basestring) for s in val))) 

793

803class _DomainCheckInterval(object): 

804 """ 

805 Define a valid interval, so that : 

806 

807 ``domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) == True`` where 

808 ``x < a`` or ``x > b``. 

809 

810 """ 

811 

812 def __init__(self, a, b): 

813 "domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) = true where x < a or y > b" 

814 if a > b: 

815 (a, b) = (b, a) 

816 self.a = a 

817 self.b = b 

818 

819 def __call__(self, x): 

820 "Execute the call behavior." 

821 # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though 

822 # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings. 

823 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

824 return umath.logical_or(umath.greater(x, self.b), 

825 umath.less(x, self.a)) 

826 

827 

828class _DomainTan(object): 

829 """ 

830 Define a valid interval for the `tan` function, so that: 

831 

832 ``domain_tan(eps) = True`` where ``abs(cos(x)) < eps`` 

833 

834 """ 

835 

836 def __init__(self, eps): 

837 "domain_tan(eps) = true where abs(cos(x)) < eps)" 

838 self.eps = eps 

839 

840 def __call__(self, x): 

841 "Executes the call behavior." 

842 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

843 return umath.less(umath.absolute(umath.cos(x)), self.eps) 

844 

845 

846class _DomainSafeDivide(object): 

847 """ 

848 Define a domain for safe division. 

849 

850 """ 

851 

852 def __init__(self, tolerance=None): 

853 self.tolerance = tolerance 

854 

855 def __call__(self, a, b): 

856 # Delay the selection of the tolerance to here in order to reduce numpy 

857 # import times. The calculation of these parameters is a substantial 

858 # component of numpy's import time. 

859 if self.tolerance is None: 

860 self.tolerance = np.finfo(float).tiny 

861 # don't call ma ufuncs from __array_wrap__ which would fail for scalars 

862 a, b = np.asarray(a), np.asarray(b) 

863 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

864 return umath.absolute(a) * self.tolerance >= umath.absolute(b)

867class _DomainGreater(object): 

868 """ 

869 DomainGreater(v)(x) is True where x <= v. 

870 

871 """ 

872 

873 def __init__(self, critical_value): 

874 "DomainGreater(v)(x) = true where x <= v" 

875 self.critical_value = critical_value 

876 

877 def __call__(self, x): 

878 "Executes the call behavior." 

879 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

880 return umath.less_equal(x, self.critical_value) 

881

884 """ 

885 DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) is True where x < v. 

886 

887 """ 

888 

889 def __init__(self, critical_value): 

890 "DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) = true where x < v" 

891 self.critical_value = critical_value 

892 

893 def __call__(self, x): 

894 "Executes the call behavior." 

895 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

896 return umath.less(x, self.critical_value)

899class _MaskedUFunc(object): 

900 def __init__(self, ufunc): 

901 self.f = ufunc 

902 self.__doc__ = ufunc.__doc__ 

903 self.__name__ = ufunc.__name__ 

904 

905 def __str__(self): 

906 return "Masked version of {}".format(self.f) 

907 

908 

909class _MaskedUnaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

910 """ 

911 Defines masked version of unary operations, where invalid values are 

912 pre-masked. 

913 

914 Parameters 

915 ---------- 

916 mufunc : callable 

917 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

918 as ``_MaskedUnaryOperation.f``. 

919 fill : scalar, optional 

920 Filling value, default is 0. 

921 domain : class instance 

922 Domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

923 classes. Default is None. 

924 

925 """ 

926 

927 def __init__(self, mufunc, fill=0, domain=None): 

928 super(_MaskedUnaryOperation, self).__init__(mufunc) 

929 self.fill = fill 

930 self.domain = domain 

931 ufunc_domain[mufunc] = domain 

932 ufunc_fills[mufunc] = fill 

933 

934 def __call__(self, a, *args, **kwargs): 

935 """ 

936 Execute the call behavior. 

937 

938 """ 

939 d = getdata(a) 

940 # Deal with domain 

941 if self.domain is not None: 

942 # Case 1.1. : Domained function 

943 # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though 

944 # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings. 

945 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

946 result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs) 

947 # Make a mask 

948 m = ~umath.isfinite(result) 

949 m |= self.domain(d) 

950 m |= getmask(a) 

951 else: 

952 # Case 1.2. : Function without a domain 

953 # Get the result and the mask 

954 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

955 result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs) 

956 m = getmask(a) 

957 

958 if not result.ndim: 

959 # Case 2.1. : The result is scalarscalar 

960 if m: 

961 return masked 

962 return result 

963 

964 if m is not nomask: 

965 # Case 2.2. The result is an array 

966 # We need to fill the invalid data back w/ the input Now, 

967 # that's plain silly: in C, we would just skip the element and 

968 # keep the original, but we do have to do it that way in Python 

969 

970 # In case result has a lower dtype than the inputs (as in 

971 # equal) 

972 try: 

973 np.copyto(result, d, where=m) 

974 except TypeError: 

975 pass 

976 # Transform to 

977 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a)) 

978 masked_result._mask = m 

979 masked_result._update_from(a) 

980 return masked_result 

981 

982 

983class _MaskedBinaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

984 """ 

985 Define masked version of binary operations, where invalid 

986 values are pre-masked. 

987 

988 Parameters 

989 ---------- 

990 mbfunc : function 

991 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

992 as ``_MaskedBinaryOperation.f``. 

993 domain : class instance 

994 Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

995 classes. Default is None. 

996 fillx : scalar, optional 

997 Filling value for the first argument, default is 0. 

998 filly : scalar, optional 

999 Filling value for the second argument, default is 0. 

1000 

1001 """ 

1002 

1003 def __init__(self, mbfunc, fillx=0, filly=0): 

1004 """ 

1005 abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined. 

1006 

1007 abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce. 

1008 

1009 """ 

1010 super(_MaskedBinaryOperation, self).__init__(mbfunc) 

1011 self.fillx = fillx 

1012 self.filly = filly 

1013 ufunc_domain[mbfunc] = None 

1014 ufunc_fills[mbfunc] = (fillx, filly) 

1015 

1016 def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): 

1017 """ 

1018 Execute the call behavior. 

1019 

1020 """ 

1021 # Get the data, as ndarray 

1022 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1023 # Get the result 

1024 with np.errstate(): 

1025 np.seterr(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore') 

1026 result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs) 

1027 # Get the mask for the result 

1028 (ma, mb) = (getmask(a), getmask(b)) 

1029 if ma is nomask: 

1030 if mb is nomask: 

1031 m = nomask 

1032 else: 

1033 m = umath.logical_or(getmaskarray(a), mb) 

1034 elif mb is nomask: 

1035 m = umath.logical_or(ma, getmaskarray(b)) 

1036 else: 

1037 m = umath.logical_or(ma, mb) 

1038 

1039 # Case 1. : scalar 

1040 if not result.ndim: 

1041 if m: 

1042 return masked 

1043 return result 

1044 

1045 # Case 2. : array 

1046 # Revert result to da where masked 

1047 if m is not nomask and m.any(): 

1048 # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values 

1049 try: 

1050 np.copyto(result, da, casting='unsafe', where=m) 

1051 except Exception: 

1052 pass 

1053 

1054 # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray 

1055 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1056 masked_result._mask = m 

1057 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

1058 masked_result._update_from(a) 

1059 elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray): 

1060 masked_result._update_from(b) 

1061 return masked_result 

1062 

1063 def reduce(self, target, axis=0, dtype=None): 

1064 """ 

1065 Reduce `target` along the given `axis`. 

1066 

1067 """ 

1068 tclass = get_masked_subclass(target) 

1069 m = getmask(target) 

1070 t = filled(target, self.filly) 

1071 if t.shape == (): 

1072 t = t.reshape(1) 

1073 if m is not nomask: 

1074 m = make_mask(m, copy=True) 

1075 m.shape = (1,) 

1076 

1077 if m is nomask: 

1078 tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis) 

1079 mr = nomask 

1080 else: 

1081 tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis, dtype=dtype or t.dtype) 

1082 mr = umath.logical_and.reduce(m, axis) 

1083 

1084 if not tr.shape: 

1085 if mr: 

1086 return masked 

1087 else: 

1088 return tr 

1089 masked_tr = tr.view(tclass) 

1090 masked_tr._mask = mr 

1091 return masked_tr 

1092 

1093 def outer(self, a, b): 

1094 """ 

1095 Return the function applied to the outer product of a and b. 

1096 

1097 """ 

1098 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1099 d = self.f.outer(da, db) 

1100 ma = getmask(a) 

1101 mb = getmask(b) 

1102 if ma is nomask and mb is nomask: 

1103 m = nomask 

1104 else: 

1105 ma = getmaskarray(a) 

1106 mb = getmaskarray(b) 

1107 m = umath.logical_or.outer(ma, mb) 

1108 if (not m.ndim) and m: 

1109 return masked 

1110 if m is not nomask: 

1111 np.copyto(d, da, where=m) 

1112 if not d.shape: 

1113 return d 

1114 masked_d = d.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1115 masked_d._mask = m 

1116 return masked_d 

1117 

1118 def accumulate(self, target, axis=0): 

1119 """Accumulate `target` along `axis` after filling with y fill 

1120 value. 

1121 

1122 """ 

1123 tclass = get_masked_subclass(target) 

1124 t = filled(target, self.filly) 

1125 result = self.f.accumulate(t, axis) 

1126 masked_result = result.view(tclass) 

1127 return masked_result 

1128 

1129 

1130 

1131class _DomainedBinaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

1132 """ 

1133 Define binary operations that have a domain, like divide. 

1134 

1135 They have no reduce, outer or accumulate. 

1136 

1137 Parameters 

1138 ---------- 

1139 mbfunc : function 

1140 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

1141 as ``_DomainedBinaryOperation.f``. 

1142 domain : class instance 

1143 Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

1144 classes. 

1145 fillx : scalar, optional 

1146 Filling value for the first argument, default is 0. 

1147 filly : scalar, optional 

1148 Filling value for the second argument, default is 0. 

1149 

1150 """ 

1151 

1152 def __init__(self, dbfunc, domain, fillx=0, filly=0): 

1153 """abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined. 

1154 abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce. 

1155 """ 

1156 super(_DomainedBinaryOperation, self).__init__(dbfunc) 

1157 self.domain = domain 

1158 self.fillx = fillx 

1159 self.filly = filly 

1160 ufunc_domain[dbfunc] = domain 

1161 ufunc_fills[dbfunc] = (fillx, filly) 

1162 

1163 def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): 

1164 "Execute the call behavior." 

1165 # Get the data 

1166 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1167 # Get the result 

1168 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

1169 result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs) 

1170 # Get the mask as a combination of the source masks and invalid 

1171 m = ~umath.isfinite(result) 

1172 m |= getmask(a) 

1173 m |= getmask(b) 

1174 # Apply the domain 

1175 domain = ufunc_domain.get(self.f, None) 

1176 if domain is not None: 

1177 m |= domain(da, db) 

1178 # Take care of the scalar case first 

1179 if not m.ndim: 

1180 if m: 

1181 return masked 

1182 else: 

1183 return result 

1184 # When the mask is True, put back da if possible 

1185 # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values 

1186 try: 

1187 np.copyto(result, 0, casting='unsafe', where=m) 

1188 # avoid using "*" since this may be overlaid 

1189 masked_da = umath.multiply(m, da) 

1190 # only add back if it can be cast safely 

1191 if np.can_cast(masked_da.dtype, result.dtype, casting='safe'): 

1192 result += masked_da 

1193 except Exception: 

1194 pass 

1195 

1196 # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray 

1197 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1198 masked_result._mask = m 

1199 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

1200 masked_result._update_from(a) 

1201 elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray): 

1202 masked_result._update_from(b) 

1203 return masked_result 

1204

1289def _replace_dtype_fields_recursive(dtype, primitive_dtype): 

1290 "Private function allowing recursion in _replace_dtype_fields." 

1291 _recurse = _replace_dtype_fields_recursive 

1292 

1293 # Do we have some name fields ? 

1294 if dtype.names is not None: 

1295 descr = [] 

1296 for name in dtype.names: 

1297 field = dtype.fields[name] 

1298 if len(field) == 3: 

1299 # Prepend the title to the name 

1300 name = (field[-1], name) 

1301 descr.append((name, _recurse(field[0], primitive_dtype))) 

1302 new_dtype = np.dtype(descr) 

1303 

1304 # Is this some kind of composite a la (float,2) 

1305 elif dtype.subdtype: 

1306 descr = list(dtype.subdtype) 

1307 descr[0] = _recurse(dtype.subdtype[0], primitive_dtype) 

1308 new_dtype = np.dtype(tuple(descr)) 

1309 

1310 # this is a primitive type, so do a direct replacement 

1311 else: 

1312 new_dtype = primitive_dtype 

1313 

1314 # preserve identity of dtypes 

1315 if new_dtype == dtype: 

1316 new_dtype = dtype 

1317 

1318 return new_dtype 

1319 

1320 

1321def _replace_dtype_fields(dtype, primitive_dtype): 

1322 """ 

1323 Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1324 

1325 Returns a new dtype object, with all fields and subtypes in the given type 

1326 recursively replaced with `primitive_dtype`. 

1327 

1328 Arguments are coerced to dtypes first. 

1329 """ 

1330 dtype = np.dtype(dtype) 

1331 primitive_dtype = np.dtype(primitive_dtype) 

1332 return _replace_dtype_fields_recursive(dtype, primitive_dtype) 

1333 

1334 

1335def make_mask_descr(ndtype): 

1336 """ 

1337 Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1338 

1339 Returns a new dtype object, with the type of all fields in `ndtype` to a 

1340 boolean type. Field names are not altered. 

1341 

1342 Parameters 

1343 ---------- 

1344 ndtype : dtype 

1345 The dtype to convert. 

1346 

1347 Returns 

1348 ------- 

1349 result : dtype 

1350 A dtype that looks like `ndtype`, the type of all fields is boolean. 

1351 

1352 Examples 

1353 -------- 

1354 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1355 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'], 

1356 ... 'formats':[np.float32, np.int64]}) 

1357 >>> dtype 

1358 dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i8')]) 

1359 >>> ma.make_mask_descr(dtype) 

1360 dtype([('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')]) 

1361 >>> ma.make_mask_descr(np.float32) 

1362 dtype('bool') 

1363 

1364 """ 

1365 return _replace_dtype_fields(ndtype, MaskType) 

1366 

1367 

1368def getmask(a): 

1369 """ 

1370 Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

1371 

1372 Return the mask of `a` as an ndarray if `a` is a `MaskedArray` and the 

1373 mask is not `nomask`, else return `nomask`. To guarantee a full array 

1374 of booleans of the same shape as a, use `getmaskarray`. 

1375 

1376 Parameters 

1377 ---------- 

1378 a : array_like 

1379 Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required. 

1380 

1381 See Also 

1382 -------- 

1383 getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

1384 getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False. 

1385 

1386 Examples 

1387 -------- 

1388 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1389 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

1390 >>> a 

1391 masked_array( 

1392 data=[[1, --], 

1393 [3, 4]], 

1394 mask=[[False, True], 

1395 [False, False]], 

1396 fill_value=2) 

1397 >>> ma.getmask(a) 

1398 array([[False, True], 

1399 [False, False]]) 

1400 

1401 Equivalently use the `MaskedArray` `mask` attribute. 

1402 

1403 >>> a.mask 

1404 array([[False, True], 

1405 [False, False]]) 

1406 

1407 Result when mask == `nomask` 

1408 

1409 >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]]) 

1410 >>> b 

1411 masked_array( 

1412 data=[[1, 2], 

1413 [3, 4]], 

1414 mask=False, 

1415 fill_value=999999) 

1416 >>> ma.nomask 

1417 False 

1418 >>> ma.getmask(b) == ma.nomask 

1419 True 

1420 >>> b.mask == ma.nomask 

1421 True 

1422 

1423 """ 

1424 return getattr(a, '_mask', nomask) 

1425 

1426 

1427get_mask = getmask 

1428 

1429 

1430def getmaskarray(arr): 

1431 """ 

1432 Return the mask of a masked array, or full boolean array of False. 

1433 

1434 Return the mask of `arr` as an ndarray if `arr` is a `MaskedArray` and 

1435 the mask is not `nomask`, else return a full boolean array of False of 

1436 the same shape as `arr`. 

1437 

1438 Parameters 

1439 ---------- 

1440 arr : array_like 

1441 Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required. 

1442 

1443 See Also 

1444 -------- 

1445 getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

1446 getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

1447 

1448 Examples 

1449 -------- 

1450 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1451 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

1452 >>> a 

1453 masked_array( 

1454 data=[[1, --], 

1455 [3, 4]], 

1456 mask=[[False, True], 

1457 [False, False]], 

1458 fill_value=2) 

1459 >>> ma.getmaskarray(a) 

1460 array([[False, True], 

1461 [False, False]]) 

1462 

1463 Result when mask == ``nomask`` 

1464 

1465 >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]]) 

1466 >>> b 

1467 masked_array( 

1468 data=[[1, 2], 

1469 [3, 4]], 

1470 mask=False, 

1471 fill_value=999999) 

1472 >>> ma.getmaskarray(b) 

1473 array([[False, False], 

1474 [False, False]]) 

1475 

1476 """ 

1477 mask = getmask(arr) 

1478 if mask is nomask: 

1479 mask = make_mask_none(np.shape(arr), getattr(arr, 'dtype', None)) 

1480 return mask 

1481 

1482 

1483def is_mask(m): 

1484 """ 

1485 Return True if m is a valid, standard mask. 

1486 

1487 This function does not check the contents of the input, only that the 

1488 type is MaskType. In particular, this function returns False if the 

1489 mask has a flexible dtype. 

1490 

1491 Parameters 

1492 ---------- 

1493 m : array_like 

1494 Array to test. 

1495 

1496 Returns 

1497 ------- 

1498 result : bool 

1499 True if `m.dtype.type` is MaskType, False otherwise. 

1500 

1501 See Also 

1502 -------- 

1503 isMaskedArray : Test whether input is an instance of MaskedArray. 

1504 

1505 Examples 

1506 -------- 

1507 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1508 >>> m = ma.masked_equal([0, 1, 0, 2, 3], 0) 

1509 >>> m 

1510 masked_array(data=[--, 1, --, 2, 3], 

1511 mask=[ True, False, True, False, False], 

1512 fill_value=0) 

1513 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1514 False 

1515 >>> ma.is_mask(m.mask) 

1516 True 

1517 

1518 Input must be an ndarray (or have similar attributes) 

1519 for it to be considered a valid mask. 

1520 

1521 >>> m = [False, True, False] 

1522 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1523 False 

1524 >>> m = np.array([False, True, False]) 

1525 >>> m 

1526 array([False, True, False]) 

1527 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1528 True 

1529 

1530 Arrays with complex dtypes don't return True. 

1531 

1532 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['monty', 'pithon'], 

1533 ... 'formats':[bool, bool]}) 

1534 >>> dtype 

1535 dtype([('monty', '|b1'), ('pithon', '|b1')]) 

1536 >>> m = np.array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False)], 

1537 ... dtype=dtype) 

1538 >>> m 

1539 array([( True, False), (False, True), ( True, False)], 

1540 dtype=[('monty', '?'), ('pithon', '?')]) 

1541 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1542 False 

1543 

1544 """ 

1545 try: 

1546 return m.dtype.type is MaskType 

1547 except AttributeError: 

1548 return False 

1549 

1550 

1551def _shrink_mask(m): 

1552 """ 

1553 Shrink a mask to nomask if possible 

1554 """ 

1555 if m.dtype.names is None and not m.any(): 

1556 return nomask 

1557 else: 

1558 return m 

1559 

1560 

1561def make_mask(m, copy=False, shrink=True, dtype=MaskType): 

1562 """ 

1563 Create a boolean mask from an array. 

1564 

1565 Return `m` as a boolean mask, creating a copy if necessary or requested. 

1566 The function can accept any sequence that is convertible to integers, 

1567 or ``nomask``. Does not require that contents must be 0s and 1s, values 

1568 of 0 are interpreted as False, everything else as True. 

1569 

1570 Parameters 

1571 ---------- 

1572 m : array_like 

1573 Potential mask. 

1574 copy : bool, optional 

1575 Whether to return a copy of `m` (True) or `m` itself (False). 

1576 shrink : bool, optional 

1577 Whether to shrink `m` to ``nomask`` if all its values are False. 

1578 dtype : dtype, optional 

1579 Data-type of the output mask. By default, the output mask has a 

1580 dtype of MaskType (bool). If the dtype is flexible, each field has 

1581 a boolean dtype. This is ignored when `m` is ``nomask``, in which 

1582 case ``nomask`` is always returned. 

1583 

1584 Returns 

1585 ------- 

1586 result : ndarray 

1587 A boolean mask derived from `m`. 

1588 

1589 Examples 

1590 -------- 

1591 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1592 >>> m = [True, False, True, True] 

1593 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1594 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1595 >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1] 

1596 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1597 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1598 >>> m = [1, 0, 2, -3] 

1599 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1600 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1601 

1602 Effect of the `shrink` parameter. 

1603 

1604 >>> m = np.zeros(4) 

1605 >>> m 

1606 array([0., 0., 0., 0.]) 

1607 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1608 False 

1609 >>> ma.make_mask(m, shrink=False) 

1610 array([False, False, False, False]) 

1611 

1612 Using a flexible `dtype`. 

1613 

1614 >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1] 

1615 >>> n = [0, 1, 0, 0] 

1616 >>> arr = [] 

1617 >>> for man, mouse in zip(m, n): 

1618 ... arr.append((man, mouse)) 

1619 >>> arr 

1620 [(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)] 

1621 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['man', 'mouse'], 

1622 ... 'formats':[np.int64, np.int64]}) 

1623 >>> arr = np.array(arr, dtype=dtype) 

1624 >>> arr 

1625 array([(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)], 

1626 dtype=[('man', '<i8'), ('mouse', '<i8')]) 

1627 >>> ma.make_mask(arr, dtype=dtype) 

1628 array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False), (True, False)], 

1629 dtype=[('man', '|b1'), ('mouse', '|b1')]) 

1630 

1631 """ 

1632 if m is nomask: 

1633 return nomask 

1634 

1635 # Make sure the input dtype is valid. 

1636 dtype = make_mask_descr(dtype) 

1637 

1638 # legacy boolean special case: "existence of fields implies true" 

1639 if isinstance(m, ndarray) and m.dtype.fields and dtype == np.bool_: 

1640 return np.ones(m.shape, dtype=dtype) 

1641 

1642 # Fill the mask in case there are missing data; turn it into an ndarray. 

1643 result = np.array(filled(m, True), copy=copy, dtype=dtype, subok=True) 

1644 # Bas les masques ! 

1645 if shrink: 

1646 result = _shrink_mask(result) 

1647 return result 

1648 

1649 

1650def make_mask_none(newshape, dtype=None): 

1651 """ 

1652 Return a boolean mask of the given shape, filled with False. 

1653 

1654 This function returns a boolean ndarray with all entries False, that can 

1655 be used in common mask manipulations. If a complex dtype is specified, the 

1656 type of each field is converted to a boolean type. 

1657 

1658 Parameters 

1659 ---------- 

1660 newshape : tuple 

1661 A tuple indicating the shape of the mask. 

1662 dtype : {None, dtype}, optional 

1663 If None, use a MaskType instance. Otherwise, use a new datatype with 

1664 the same fields as `dtype`, converted to boolean types. 

1665 

1666 Returns 

1667 ------- 

1668 result : ndarray 

1669 An ndarray of appropriate shape and dtype, filled with False. 

1670 

1671 See Also 

1672 -------- 

1673 make_mask : Create a boolean mask from an array. 

1674 make_mask_descr : Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1675 

1676 Examples 

1677 -------- 

1678 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1679 >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,)) 

1680 array([False, False, False]) 

1681 

1682 Defining a more complex dtype. 

1683 

1684 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'], 

1685 ... 'formats':[np.float32, np.int64]}) 

1686 >>> dtype 

1687 dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i8')]) 

1688 >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,), dtype=dtype) 

1689 array([(False, False), (False, False), (False, False)], 

1690 dtype=[('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')]) 

1691 

1692 """ 

1693 if dtype is None: 

1694 result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=MaskType) 

1695 else: 

1696 result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=make_mask_descr(dtype)) 

1697 return result 

1698 

1699 

1700def mask_or(m1, m2, copy=False, shrink=True): 

1701 """ 

1702 Combine two masks with the ``logical_or`` operator. 

1703 

1704 The result may be a view on `m1` or `m2` if the other is `nomask` 

1705 (i.e. False). 

1706 

1707 Parameters 

1708 ---------- 

1709 m1, m2 : array_like 

1710 Input masks. 

1711 copy : bool, optional 

1712 If copy is False and one of the inputs is `nomask`, return a view 

1713 of the other input mask. Defaults to False. 

1714 shrink : bool, optional 

1715 Whether to shrink the output to `nomask` if all its values are 

1716 False. Defaults to True. 

1717 

1718 Returns 

1719 ------- 

1720 mask : output mask 

1721 The result masks values that are masked in either `m1` or `m2`. 

1722 

1723 Raises 

1724 ------ 

1725 ValueError 

1726 If `m1` and `m2` have different flexible dtypes. 

1727 

1728 Examples 

1729 -------- 

1730 >>> m1 = np.ma.make_mask([0, 1, 1, 0]) 

1731 >>> m2 = np.ma.make_mask([1, 0, 0, 0]) 

1732 >>> np.ma.mask_or(m1, m2) 

1733 array([ True, True, True, False]) 

1734 

1735 """ 

1736 

1737 @recursive 

1738 def _recursive_mask_or(self, m1, m2, newmask): 

1739 names = m1.dtype.names 

1740 for name in names: 

1741 current1 = m1[name] 

1742 if current1.dtype.names is not None: 

1743 self(current1, m2[name], newmask[name]) 

1744 else: 

1745 umath.logical_or(current1, m2[name], newmask[name]) 

1746 return 

1747 

1748 if (m1 is nomask) or (m1 is False): 

1749 dtype = getattr(m2, 'dtype', MaskType) 

1750 return make_mask(m2, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype) 

1751 if (m2 is nomask) or (m2 is False): 

1752 dtype = getattr(m1, 'dtype', MaskType) 

1753 return make_mask(m1, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype) 

1754 if m1 is m2 and is_mask(m1): 

1755 return m1 

1756 (dtype1, dtype2) = (getattr(m1, 'dtype', None), getattr(m2, 'dtype', None)) 

1757 if dtype1 != dtype2: 

1758 raise ValueError("Incompatible dtypes '%s'<>'%s'" % (dtype1, dtype2)) 

1759 if dtype1.names is not None: 

1760 # Allocate an output mask array with the properly broadcast shape. 

1761 newmask = np.empty(np.broadcast(m1, m2).shape, dtype1) 

1762 _recursive_mask_or(m1, m2, newmask) 

1763 return newmask 

1764 return make_mask(umath.logical_or(m1, m2), copy=copy, shrink=shrink) 

1765 

1766 

1767def flatten_mask(mask): 

1768 """ 

1769 Returns a completely flattened version of the mask, where nested fields 

1770 are collapsed. 

1771 

1772 Parameters 

1773 ---------- 

1774 mask : array_like 

1775 Input array, which will be interpreted as booleans. 

1776 

1777 Returns 

1778 ------- 

1779 flattened_mask : ndarray of bools 

1780 The flattened input. 

1781 

1782 Examples 

1783 -------- 

1784 >>> mask = np.array([0, 0, 1]) 

1785 >>> np.ma.flatten_mask(mask) 

1786 array([False, False, True]) 

1787 

1788 >>> mask = np.array([(0, 0), (0, 1)], dtype=[('a', bool), ('b', bool)]) 

1789 >>> np.ma.flatten_mask(mask) 

1790 array([False, False, False, True]) 

1791 

1792 >>> mdtype = [('a', bool), ('b', [('ba', bool), ('bb', bool)])] 

1793 >>> mask = np.array([(0, (0, 0)), (0, (0, 1))], dtype=mdtype) 

1794 >>> np.ma.flatten_mask(mask) 

1795 array([False, False, False, False, False, True]) 

1796 

1797 """ 

1798 

1799 def _flatmask(mask): 

1800 "Flatten the mask and returns a (maybe nested) sequence of booleans." 

1801 mnames = mask.dtype.names 

1802 if mnames is not None: 

1803 return [flatten_mask(mask[name]) for name in mnames] 

1804 else: 

1805 return mask 

1806 

1807 def _flatsequence(sequence): 

1808 "Generates a flattened version of the sequence." 

1809 try: 

1810 for element in sequence: 

1811 if hasattr(element, '__iter__'): 

1812 for f in _flatsequence(element): 

1813 yield f 

1814 else: 

1815 yield element 

1816 except TypeError: 

1817 yield sequence 

1818 

1819 mask = np.asarray(mask) 

1820 flattened = _flatsequence(_flatmask(mask)) 

1821 return np.array([_ for _ in flattened], dtype=bool) 

1822 

1823 

1824def _check_mask_axis(mask, axis, keepdims=np._NoValue): 

1825 "Check whether there are masked values along the given axis" 

1826 kwargs = {} if keepdims is np._NoValue else {'keepdims': keepdims} 

1827 if mask is not nomask: 

1828 return mask.all(axis=axis, **kwargs) 

1829 return nomask 

1830

1832############################################################################### 

1833# Masking functions # 

1834############################################################################### 

1835 

1836def masked_where(condition, a, copy=True): 

1837 """ 

1838 Mask an array where a condition is met. 

1839 

1840 Return `a` as an array masked where `condition` is True. 

1841 Any masked values of `a` or `condition` are also masked in the output. 

1842 

1843 Parameters 

1844 ---------- 

1845 condition : array_like 

1846 Masking condition. When `condition` tests floating point values for 

1847 equality, consider using ``masked_values`` instead. 

1848 a : array_like 

1849 Array to mask. 

1850 copy : bool 

1851 If True (default) make a copy of `a` in the result. If False modify 

1852 `a` in place and return a view. 

1853 

1854 Returns 

1855 ------- 

1856 result : MaskedArray 

1857 The result of masking `a` where `condition` is True. 

1858 

1859 See Also 

1860 -------- 

1861 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality. 

1862 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value. 

1863 masked_not_equal : Mask where `not` equal to a given value. 

1864 masked_less_equal : Mask where less than or equal to a given value. 

1865 masked_greater_equal : Mask where greater than or equal to a given value. 

1866 masked_less : Mask where less than a given value. 

1867 masked_greater : Mask where greater than a given value. 

1868 masked_inside : Mask inside a given interval. 

1869 masked_outside : Mask outside a given interval. 

1870 masked_invalid : Mask invalid values (NaNs or infs). 

1871 

1872 Examples 

1873 -------- 

1874 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1875 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1876 >>> a 

1877 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1878 >>> ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a) 

1879 masked_array(data=[--, --, --, 3], 

1880 mask=[ True, True, True, False], 

1881 fill_value=999999) 

1882 

1883 Mask array `b` conditional on `a`. 

1884 

1885 >>> b = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] 

1886 >>> ma.masked_where(a == 2, b) 

1887 masked_array(data=['a', 'b', --, 'd'], 

1888 mask=[False, False, True, False], 

1889 fill_value='N/A', 

1890 dtype='<U1') 

1891 

1892 Effect of the `copy` argument. 

1893 

1894 >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a) 

1895 >>> c 

1896 masked_array(data=[--, --, --, 3], 

1897 mask=[ True, True, True, False], 

1898 fill_value=999999) 

1899 >>> c[0] = 99 

1900 >>> c 

1901 masked_array(data=[99, --, --, 3], 

1902 mask=[False, True, True, False], 

1903 fill_value=999999) 

1904 >>> a 

1905 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1906 >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a, copy=False) 

1907 >>> c[0] = 99 

1908 >>> c 

1909 masked_array(data=[99, --, --, 3], 

1910 mask=[False, True, True, False], 

1911 fill_value=999999) 

1912 >>> a 

1913 array([99, 1, 2, 3]) 

1914 

1915 When `condition` or `a` contain masked values. 

1916 

1917 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1918 >>> a = ma.masked_where(a == 2, a) 

1919 >>> a 

1920 masked_array(data=[0, 1, --, 3], 

1921 mask=[False, False, True, False], 

1922 fill_value=999999) 

1923 >>> b = np.arange(4) 

1924 >>> b = ma.masked_where(b == 0, b) 

1925 >>> b 

1926 masked_array(data=[--, 1, 2, 3], 

1927 mask=[ True, False, False, False], 

1928 fill_value=999999) 

1929 >>> ma.masked_where(a == 3, b) 

1930 masked_array(data=[--, 1, --, --], 

1931 mask=[ True, False, True, True], 

1932 fill_value=999999) 

1933 

1934 """ 

1935 # Make sure that condition is a valid standard-type mask. 

1936 cond = make_mask(condition, shrink=False) 

1937 a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True) 

1938 

1939 (cshape, ashape) = (cond.shape, a.shape) 

1940 if cshape and cshape != ashape: 

1941 raise IndexError("Inconsistent shape between the condition and the input" 

1942 " (got %s and %s)" % (cshape, ashape)) 

1943 if hasattr(a, '_mask'): 

1944 cond = mask_or(cond, a._mask) 

1945 cls = type(a) 

1946 else: 

1947 cls = MaskedArray 

1948 result = a.view(cls) 

1949 # Assign to *.mask so that structured masks are handled correctly. 

1950 result.mask = _shrink_mask(cond) 

1951 return result 

1952 

1953 

1954def masked_greater(x, value, copy=True): 

1955 """ 

1956 Mask an array where greater than a given value. 

1957 

1958 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

1959 `condition` = (x > value). 

1960 

1961 See Also 

1962 -------- 

1963 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

1964 

1965 Examples 

1966 -------- 

1967 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1968 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1969 >>> a 

1970 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1971 >>> ma.masked_greater(a, 2) 

1972 masked_array(data=[0, 1, 2, --], 

1973 mask=[False, False, False, True], 

1974 fill_value=999999) 

1975 

1976 """ 

1977 return masked_where(greater(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

1978 

1979 

1980def masked_greater_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

1981 """ 

1982 Mask an array where greater than or equal to a given value. 

1983 

1984 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

1985 `condition` = (x >= value). 

1986 

1987 See Also 

1988 -------- 

1989 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

1990 

1991 Examples 

1992 -------- 

1993 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1994 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1995 >>> a 

1996 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1997 >>> ma.masked_greater_equal(a, 2) 

1998 masked_array(data=[0, 1, --, --], 

1999 mask=[False, False, True, True], 

2000 fill_value=999999) 

2001 

2002 """ 

2003 return masked_where(greater_equal(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

2004 

2005 

2006def masked_less(x, value, copy=True): 

2007 """ 

2008 Mask an array where less than a given value. 

2009 

2010 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2011 `condition` = (x < value). 

2012 

2013 See Also 

2014 -------- 

2015 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2016 

2017 Examples 

2018 -------- 

2019 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2020 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

2021 >>> a 

2022 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

2023 >>> ma.masked_less(a, 2) 

2024 masked_array(data=[--, --, 2, 3], 

2025 mask=[ True, True, False, False], 

2026 fill_value=999999) 

2027 

2028 """ 

2029 return masked_where(less(x, value), x, copy=copy)

2084def masked_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

2085 """ 

2086 Mask an array where equal to a given value. 

2087 

2088 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2089 `condition` = (x == value). For floating point arrays,

2095 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality.

2099 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2100 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

2101 >>> a

2103 >>> ma.masked_equal(a, 2) 

2104 masked_array(data=[0, 1, --, 3], 

2105 mask=[False, False, True, False], 

2106 fill_value=2) 

2107 

2108 """ 

2109 output = masked_where(equal(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

2110 output.fill_value = value 

2111 return output

2114def masked_inside(x, v1, v2, copy=True): 

2115 """ 

2116 Mask an array inside a given interval. 

2117 

2118 Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` inside 

2119 the interval [v1,v2] (v1 <= x <= v2). The boundaries `v1` and `v2` 

2120 can be given in either order. 

2121 

2122 See Also 

2123 -------- 

2124 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2125 

2126 Notes 

2127 ----- 

2128 The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value. 

2129 

2130 Examples 

2131 -------- 

2132 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2133 >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1] 

2134 >>> ma.masked_inside(x, -0.3, 0.3) 

2135 masked_array(data=[0.31, 1.2, --, --, -0.4, -1.1], 

2136 mask=[False, False, True, True, False, False], 

2137 fill_value=1e+20) 

2138 

2139 The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter. 

2140 

2141 >>> ma.masked_inside(x, 0.3, -0.3) 

2142 masked_array(data=[0.31, 1.2, --, --, -0.4, -1.1], 

2143 mask=[False, False, True, True, False, False], 

2144 fill_value=1e+20) 

2145 

2146 """ 

2147 if v2 < v1: 

2148 (v1, v2) = (v2, v1) 

2149 xf = filled(x) 

2150 condition = (xf >= v1) & (xf <= v2) 

2151 return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy) 

2152 

2153 

2154def masked_outside(x, v1, v2, copy=True): 

2155 """ 

2156 Mask an array outside a given interval. 

2157 

2158 Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` outside 

2159 the interval [v1,v2] (x < v1)|(x > v2). 

2160 The boundaries `v1` and `v2` can be given in either order. 

2161 

2162 See Also 

2163 -------- 

2164 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2165 

2166 Notes 

2167 ----- 

2168 The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value. 

2169 

2170 Examples 

2171 -------- 

2172 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2173 >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1] 

2174 >>> ma.masked_outside(x, -0.3, 0.3) 

2175 masked_array(data=[--, --, 0.01, 0.2, --, --], 

2176 mask=[ True, True, False, False, True, True], 

2177 fill_value=1e+20) 

2178 

2179 The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter. 

2180 

2181 >>> ma.masked_outside(x, 0.3, -0.3) 

2182 masked_array(data=[--, --, 0.01, 0.2, --, --], 

2183 mask=[ True, True, False, False, True, True], 

2184 fill_value=1e+20) 

2185 

2186 """ 

2187 if v2 < v1: 

2188 (v1, v2) = (v2, v1) 

2189 xf = filled(x) 

2190 condition = (xf < v1) | (xf > v2) 

2191 return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy)

2194def masked_object(x, value, copy=True, shrink=True): 

2195 """ 

2196 Mask the array `x` where the data are exactly equal to value. 

2197 

2198 This function is similar to `masked_values`, but only suitable 

2199 for object arrays: for floating point, use `masked_values` instead. 

2200 

2201 Parameters 

2202 ---------- 

2203 x : array_like 

2204 Array to mask 

2205 value : object 

2206 Comparison value 

2207 copy : {True, False}, optional 

2208 Whether to return a copy of `x`. 

2209 shrink : {True, False}, optional 

2210 Whether to collapse a mask full of False to nomask 

2211 

2212 Returns 

2213 ------- 

2214 result : MaskedArray 

2215 The result of masking `x` where equal to `value`. 

2216 

2217 See Also 

2218 -------- 

2219 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2220 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers). 

2221 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality. 

2222 

2223 Examples 

2224 -------- 

2225 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2226 >>> food = np.array(['green_eggs', 'ham'], dtype=object) 

2227 >>> # don't eat spoiled food 

2228 >>> eat = ma.masked_object(food, 'green_eggs') 

2229 >>> eat 

2230 masked_array(data=[--, 'ham'], 

2231 mask=[ True, False], 

2232 fill_value='green_eggs', 

2233 dtype=object) 

2234 >>> # plain ol` ham is boring 

2235 >>> fresh_food = np.array(['cheese', 'ham', 'pineapple'], dtype=object) 

2236 >>> eat = ma.masked_object(fresh_food, 'green_eggs') 

2237 >>> eat 

2238 masked_array(data=['cheese', 'ham', 'pineapple'], 

2239 mask=False, 

2240 fill_value='green_eggs', 

2241 dtype=object) 

2242 

2243 Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible. 

2244 

2245 >>> eat 

2246 masked_array(data=['cheese', 'ham', 'pineapple'], 

2247 mask=False, 

2248 fill_value='green_eggs', 

2249 dtype=object) 

2250 

2251 """ 

2252 if isMaskedArray(x): 

2253 condition = umath.equal(x._data, value) 

2254 mask = x._mask 

2255 else: 

2256 condition = umath.equal(np.asarray(x), value) 

2257 mask = nomask 

2258 mask = mask_or(mask, make_mask(condition, shrink=shrink)) 

2259 return masked_array(x, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value) 

2260 

2261 

2262def masked_values(x, value, rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-8, copy=True, shrink=True): 

2263 """ 

2264 Mask using floating point equality. 

2265 

2266 Return a MaskedArray, masked where the data in array `x` are approximately 

2267 equal to `value`, determined using `isclose`. The default tolerances for 

2268 `masked_values` are the same as those for `isclose`. 

2269 

2270 For integer types, exact equality is used, in the same way as 

2271 `masked_equal`. 

2272 

2273 The fill_value is set to `value` and the mask is set to ``nomask`` if 

2274 possible. 

2275 

2276 Parameters 

2277 ---------- 

2278 x : array_like 

2279 Array to mask. 

2280 value : float 

2281 Masking value. 

2282 rtol, atol : float, optional 

2283 Tolerance parameters passed on to `isclose` 

2284 copy : bool, optional 

2285 Whether to return a copy of `x`. 

2286 shrink : bool, optional 

2287 Whether to collapse a mask full of False to ``nomask``. 

2288 

2289 Returns 

2290 ------- 

2291 result : MaskedArray 

2292 The result of masking `x` where approximately equal to `value`. 

2293 

2294 See Also 

2295 -------- 

2296 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2297 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers). 

2298 

2299 Examples 

2300 -------- 

2301 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2302 >>> x = np.array([1, 1.1, 2, 1.1, 3]) 

2303 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.1) 

2304 masked_array(data=[1.0, --, 2.0, --, 3.0], 

2305 mask=[False, True, False, True, False], 

2306 fill_value=1.1) 

2307 

2308 Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible. 

2309 

2310 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.5) 

2311 masked_array(data=[1. , 1.1, 2. , 1.1, 3. ], 

2312 mask=False, 

2313 fill_value=1.5) 

2314 

2315 For integers, the fill value will be different in general to the 

2316 result of ``masked_equal``. 

2317 

2318 >>> x = np.arange(5) 

2319 >>> x 

2320 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2321 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 2) 

2322 masked_array(data=[0, 1, --, 3, 4], 

2323 mask=[False, False, True, False, False], 

2324 fill_value=2) 

2325 >>> ma.masked_equal(x, 2) 

2326 masked_array(data=[0, 1, --, 3, 4], 

2327 mask=[False, False, True, False, False], 

2328 fill_value=2) 

2329 

2330 """ 

2331 xnew = filled(x, value) 

2332 if np.issubdtype(xnew.dtype, np.floating): 

2333 mask = np.isclose(xnew, value, atol=atol, rtol=rtol) 

2334 else: 

2335 mask = umath.equal(xnew, value) 

2336 ret = masked_array(xnew, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value) 

2337 if shrink: 

2338 ret.shrink_mask() 

2339 return ret 

2340 

2341 

2342def masked_invalid(a, copy=True): 

2343 """ 

2344 Mask an array where invalid values occur (NaNs or infs). 

2345 

2346 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2347 `condition` = ~(np.isfinite(a)). Any pre-existing mask is conserved. 

2348 Only applies to arrays with a dtype where NaNs or infs make sense 

2349 (i.e. floating point types), but accepts any array_like object. 

2350 

2351 See Also 

2352 -------- 

2353 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2354 

2355 Examples 

2356 -------- 

2357 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2358 >>> a = np.arange(5, dtype=float) 

2359 >>> a[2] = np.NaN 

2360 >>> a[3] = np.PINF 

2361 >>> a 

2362 array([ 0., 1., nan, inf, 4.]) 

2363 >>> ma.masked_invalid(a) 

2364 masked_array(data=[0.0, 1.0, --, --, 4.0], 

2365 mask=[False, False, True, True, False], 

2366 fill_value=1e+20) 

2367 

2368 """ 

2369 a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True) 

2370 mask = getattr(a, '_mask', None) 

2371 if mask is not None: 

2372 condition = ~(np.isfinite(getdata(a))) 

2373 if mask is not nomask: 

2374 condition |= mask 

2375 cls = type(a) 

2376 else: 

2377 condition = ~(np.isfinite(a)) 

2378 cls = MaskedArray 

2379 result = a.view(cls) 

2380 result._mask = condition 

2381 return result 

2382

2440def _recursive_printoption(result, mask, printopt): 

2441 """ 

2442 Puts printoptions in result where mask is True. 

2443 

2444 Private function allowing for recursion 

2445 

2446 """ 

2447 names = result.dtype.names 

2448 if names is not None: 

2449 for name in names: 

2450 curdata = result[name] 

2451 curmask = mask[name] 

2452 _recursive_printoption(curdata, curmask, printopt) 

2453 else: 

2454 np.copyto(result, printopt, where=mask) 

2455 return 

2456

2458_legacy_print_templates = dict( 

2459 long_std=textwrap.dedent("""\ 

2460 masked_%(name)s(data = 

2461 %(data)s, 

2462 %(nlen)s mask = 

2463 %(mask)s, 

2464 %(nlen)s fill_value = %(fill)s) 

2465 """), 

2466 long_flx=textwrap.dedent("""\ 

2467 masked_%(name)s(data = 

2468 %(data)s, 

2469 %(nlen)s mask = 

2470 %(mask)s, 

2471 %(nlen)s fill_value = %(fill)s, 

2472 %(nlen)s dtype = %(dtype)s) 

2473 """), 

2474 short_std=textwrap.dedent("""\ 

2475 masked_%(name)s(data = %(data)s, 

2476 %(nlen)s mask = %(mask)s, 

2477 %(nlen)s fill_value = %(fill)s) 

2478 """), 

2479 short_flx=textwrap.dedent("""\

2482 %(nlen)s fill_value = %(fill)s,
